dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faded lettering on her shallow draft hull informs us she' the “RAMONA". A poacher's pride and joy, stocked with NET TRAPS, CANISTERS: tools of the trade, but in this instanc chosen with a single prey in mind. From inside the CREW CABIN we can just hear a SINGLE, EXHAUSTED VOICE, speakin Portugese, and, very low on the soundtrack, STRANGE MUSIC Brazilian pop, playing half-speed... . “INT. RAMONA CREW CABIN NIGHT The musica bit louder; the VOICE, still off-screen, more obviously desperate. THE CAMERA takes in the cramped quarters, illuminated by the flickering light of an OIL L There is a single chair and a small table and FOUR BUNKS, each one showing evidence of having been recently occupied...a duffel bag near one, clothes strewn about — another, yet another unmade with a BOOMBOX resting near t Pillow. THE MUSIC comes from the boombox: we see a tape ~ spinning, slower and slower, as the batteries die... The camera comes to a rest on the source of the voice: an older INDIAN MAN, his face scarred and glistening with th sweat of fear. He sits before a SHORTWAVE RADIO, frantica (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: attempting to bring the dead piece of hardware to life-- twisting the dial, babbling into the mike. All in vain: w don't even hear static from the radio. .- A SUDDEN SMALL BUMP shakes the boat, and the POACHER. He freezes for a moment, then quickly rises, grabbing a NEAR GUN and a HAMMER. He moves to the door, passing a picture tacked on the wall: ‘THE PICTURE shows THREE MEN, proudly holding a LARGE SNAKE, about twenty feet long. The SNAKE mazzled and harnassed with high tech trapping apparati. W recognize one of the men as the poacher...the second man Indian features. The third is a particulerly cocky . ‘Caucasian, wearing a T-shirt with the ROLLING STONES TRADEMARK tongue on it. EXT. BOAT DECK WIGHT. The Poacher dares to emerge. He looks around, firearm leveled. He mumbles in Portugese...threats mixed with ple punctuated by prayers, the ramblings of a schizophrenic.. he crosses the deck, his eyes darting to the river. S-SHAPED WAVES roll across the dark water's surface and l against the hull, rocking the boat. He gets on all fours uses the hammer claw to pry planks from the wooden deck. A bucket rolls across the deck. He spins, FIRES, CLANGS a hole through it. Hesitates, goes back to his chore, still mumbling.. He tears up some deck planks, drags them into cabin and slams the door. We hear now HAMMERING SOUNDS.

dialogues.text: The poacher begins to nail wood planks to the doorframe.. POV-- UNDERWATER | ‘ The unseen presence seems to be. casing the boat, tooking the most valnerable area of attack.

dialogues.text: ’ Nailed inside the cabin, the poacher backs to the table taking a swig of liquor before moving back to the radio. he simply hits it. And now we hear a sputter of static. — HOPE. He picks up the mike and begins to talk into it but just that moment: .

dialogues.text: eyes, wide with terror, lock on the floorboards. More . BUMPING AND THUMPING. Little by little the old floorboard are giving way, the rusty nails shaking loose. The Poache leaps across the cramped room and begins prying off the planks which he'd just nailed over the door. The floorboards are buckling up and splintering. The Poac whimpers and cries, his hands bloodied and fingernails sp as he yanks the boards from the door. Suddenly, the floorboards all splinter up -- just. as the Poacher frees himself out the door. : “ :

dialogues.text: The Poacher scrambles up the few steep steps to the cabin roof. He looks behind him and seés something terrifying. climbs to the top of the mast rising above the cabin. .

dialogues.text: He's totally crazed. Lips aquiver. Sweat streaming. He looks down, gasps in terror and quickly pulls his legs up far as he can -~ something's coming. He starts to recite LORD'S PRAYER in Portugese as he takes the GUN and shoots into the water-- once, twice, three times. Again, in vain. The boat is being violently rocked by the attacking creature. He checks his gun, sees that he has o bullet left. He is beyond fear now: seems somehow at peac as he puts the gun to his head, finishing his prayer.

dialogues.text: C) The VAN slams on its brakes, screeching to a stop, bar \ missing an INDIAN MAN lugging a large basket of fruit. occupants of the Van lurch against the seats. The Indian Man moves on, after giving the driver of the v an international hand signal, and the van continues to navigate the clatter and color of Manaus: NATIVES in feat walking among CITY PEOPLE in business suits...KIDS playin soccer in a muddy field that is flanked by modern office buildings....STREET VENDORS selling everything they own....STREET WALKERS selling everything imaginable. see 11A EXT. DOCK - DAY 11a ’ The van passes across a bridge onto the dock teeming wi PEOPLE coming and going. CRATES filled with electronic go soda, beer, BARGES heavily laden. BOATS of all sizes and shapes -- RIVERBOATS preparing for a long journey, hammoc swinging from their decks, maybe a band plays as one riverboat pulls out. The van pulls up next to a waiting SPEEDBOAT The ARIAU JU TOWER HOTEL printed across the stern and disgorges the jostled occupants. First out is GARY, a handsome American © shoots a look at TERRI PORTER, an attractive woman in h ” twenties, confident, tough, independent. Terri's been r in the front passenger seat: GARY'S expression seems to s "What have you gotten us in to". GARY helps DENISE KALBERG, early twenties, a fresh, small town scrubbed quality about her, as they unload their equipment. From their body language and playful manner it apparent that they are lovers. Denise wears a funky jewel erucifix from her neck.

Terri, Denise, and Ga step out and start to unload their luggage. Denise throws arms around Gary, excited. They take a moment to share a passionate kiss. Terri watches them for a beat, wistful, before carrying her gear into the hotel. .

Danny. breaks into a huge grin. He stands

They're out there. Completely isolated. They have their own customs, myths, religion. Unique. Unlike anything we've experienced. What if we pollute that?

dialogues.speaker: WESTRIDGE
dialogues.text: Our adventure begins one thousand miles from the mouth of the mighty Amazon, deep in the heart of the rainforest. We will travel by river barge up through shallow tributaries and unexplored backwaters in search of the elusive "People of the Mist", the Shirishama Tribe. The Shirishama have lived in complete isolation and harmony with nature for hundreds of years. Dr. Steven Cale, a - leading expert on this tribe, will be accompanying us on our trek to help unravel the mysteries of the Sbirishama. (BEAT) God, that's a mouthful.

The air crackles. Westridge looks for a place to sit, but everything seems filthy. He takes a handkerchief from his pocket and spreads it on a suitable spot. ANGLE: . ce - 2aas The clouds seem to suddenly expand, turning the color of lead, darkening the immediate area. A BOLT OF LIGHTNING SPLITS THE SKY, and everyone RUNS FOR COVER as a torrenti tropic storm pours sheets of rain onto the barge. Mateo struggles in the strong wind to pilot the barge up churning brown river. Everyone hides from the rain under leaking canvas tenting that is draped across the deck. They all look numb and miserable and vulnerable to the powers of nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The torrential rains continue. Mateo squints into the win and is barely able to see the shoreline because the rain so heavy. But he's looking very carefully. The barge rounds a bend, and Danny sees it first: the sha of something in the mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Over there! A BOAT, gray and heavy, tilting in the water. One by one, the others see the boat... It appears to be abandoned as ‘sags heavily, anchored but lurching from the churning wa Terri points: aman stands on ‘the deck of the boat, his ‘loose clothing flapping in the wind. Soaked and desperat he: waves ‘his arms frantically at them, shouting words t cannot hear. . Terri calls to Mateo over the howling wind

dialogues.speaker: TERRI
dialogues.text: Get close to his boat! We'll bring him aboard! ‘

dialogues.speaker: MATEO
dialogues.text: No. You trust nobody on these waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subdued ) "Pull over to his boat. Mateo maneuvers toward the crippled boat. Danny has his camera on his shoulder. Gary and Denise are taping the vicious sounds of the winds and rain. Mateo smiles ever s slyly. The form becomes a man as the two boats get closer. PAUL SARONE is tall, strong and handsome with a commanding physical presence, obvious even as he stands soaked. - The two boats come close, Gary grabs.a rope and heaves across the gap to Sarone. Gary wraps it around a cleat as Sarone pulls the barge a little closer.

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: Catch! Sarone throws a duffel bag to Gary, who catches it. Then another. Gary plops the duffel bags down. Sarone dives in river and Cale, Gary, and Terri haul him aboard. He is bo hot and cold, shivering as they lead him beneath some tenting. Gary pours brandy into a cup and Denise wraps an about his shoulders. Sarone drinks down the brandy with o fast gulp, barely taking note of the people around him. TERRI oo . . You okay? . .

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: I. think so. Storm surge pushed me into the shallows, my propeller caught a ‘rock. God knows how long I'd have been stuck here. : ‘CALE We can't take you back to Manaus. We're headed up river. :

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: If you can just get me to the next village, I know the people. They'1l help me fix my boat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: Glances all around: no one has any problems with that.

dialogues.text: Am I going to be on the news? Sarone's good humor disarms the crew. Everyone laughs exc Mateo. Sarone looks up to Mateo. Mateo regards him with s mysterious knowledge: he knows this man, or men like him.

dialogues.text: Later.now, the storm has ended. The water is calm and the - has cleared. The boat is anchored along the shore. Dann stands at the back of the boat filming. Terri, Cale, and Westridge watch as:

dialogues.text: Fish river style. Sarone climbs into the boat. - He whips out a knife and efficiently guts and cleans the fish. Gary and Denise have come out of their cabin. Gary watches, mesmerized by Sarone's skill. TERRI ' . Ever work in a sushi bar, Mr. Sarone?

dialogues.text: iN ()

dialogues.text: shooting Script - pecember 1 21. How long. have you been on the river, Mr. Sarone?

dialogues.text: Where're. you from?

dialogues.text: What brought you here?

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Fate. Bad karma. I started out studying for the Priesthood. After spending so much time inside I figured I needed to get out. See the real world. Somehow I ended up here. Guess I fit in.

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: I catch reptiles: for zoos and collectors. Whatever they want.

dialogues.speaker: . SARONE

dialogues.speaker: GARY 6
dialogues.text: And now you're hunting?

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: Snakes. Mostly.

dialogues.text: I hate snakes.

dialogues.text: SARONE ° And you all? What are you | hunting? WESTRIDGE . . We're not hunting anything. We're making a filn.

dialogues.text: - | The People of The Mist.

dialogues.text: (laughing) Five whiskeys? That's breakfast on the river. (BEAT) How are you going to find them? CALE . The Shirishama follow the seasons and the eclipses. As part of their religion. We're following the lunar calendar.

dialogues.text: -Would.a salad go well with ‘fish river style'? SARONE wt Perfect. Denise hands him the skillet. Sarone expertly salts and : ss the large fish, rubs some oil on it, and drope it in. the skillet. The fish pops and sizzles. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: We don't need any help, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: . SARONE
dialogues.text: Look. You've been very kind. I feel I'm getting in the way... : Whatever help you'can give us, whatever you can tell us about the river....

dialogues.speaker: . SARONE
dialogues.text: I owe you. If there is a spare hammock, a good night's sleep is all I need, and in the morning I can show you where I last saw the Shirishama.

dialogues.text: C) The remains of dinner lay scattered around the table. \ Westridge kills bugs with a spray can. Gary and Denise, _ loaded down with sound equipment climb ashore. Danny st out his cigarillo.

dialogues.text: Fed the ‘bugs. Time for me to turn in. ‘Good night. Danny stands and goes into his cabin..

dialogues.text: However unsavory, at least his reputation is known. It's the hitch hiker that concerns me. Unbeknownst to them, Sarone stands twenty feet back, watc them, concerned. Westridge leans close to Terri and Cale. ‘WESTRIDGE . He's a poacher by his own admission.

dialogues.text: There is a thick mist in the air as the anchored barge re close to the shore, bobbing gently in the steamy water. T night songs of animals and insects blend as a single, constant sound, which is overridden by the cool clatter o Miles Davis and Max Roach blasting loudly from a beat box A SUBTLE RIPPLE upsets the otherwise still black river...

dialogues.text: Terri and Cale stand on the side of the barge and look ou over the quietly flowing river. Terri holds a map and sma flashlight. ‘Only the glow of a cigarette reveals Sarone, - watching, deep in the shadows. TERRI . Sarone says wé've got a better chance of encountering the Shirishama here. What do you think?

dialogues.text: He's been there. That's a distinct advantage. Although, Westridge could be right...Mr. Sarone could be some pathological liar who suffers from delusions of machismo. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: mm. Interesting theory, Dr. Cale. O can : Don't tell me you like that...that...Adventure-land, Crocodile Dundee stuff?

dialogues.text: I. guess I deserve that. But I want you to know that my wandering days are behind

dialogues.text: I happen to. be a very wealthy man. DANNY , cos Great. Spare a twenty?

dialogues.text: If you continue to play that music, I will hire someone to kill you. A . tribesman with a blow gun and a poison ~ dart and a need and a use for five : thousand American dollars. Comprende? —. : ‘ Danny turns the music down, just enough to hear.

dialogues.text: Denise and Gary have found a small clearing in the jungle about a hundred yards from shore; they have their equipme out and are listening to the sounds of the jungle: a symp of insect noises, wind, and distant mammal chatters which peculiarly sensual to the two. Their eyes meet. Denise an Gary both feel the strange, wild lust of the jungle. . Suddenly, they'ze in each other's arms with a passionate kiss. Gary breaks from her and clicks on the Nagra.

dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.text: They want wild sounds? Let's give them some. Denise laughs as Gary peels off her blouse. ‘The sounds . gonsume them, engulf them, fade off as they become lost each other... Denise freezes as her eyes pop wide open.

dialogues.text: What? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: The silence.... The night is suddenly, completely silent. POV from a distance: they are being watched. Gary turns on his ‘ flashlight as Denise slips back into her clothes. He shin the flashlight in one direction, then quickly in another. Whirling around, he flashes the light at the sound behind chim: the breaking of a twig. Nothing there. Just lush jungle. A false alarm. They relax... Then another sound. A snap. He whispers to Denise.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Let's get the hell out of here. : But the flashlight has caught something, and Denise is staring in shock. TWO GLOWING EYES of a snorting creature Terrified, Denise takes a step backward, then turns to ru and lands SMACK AGAINST A TALL FIGURE. It's Sarone.

He keeps his gun aimed until he recognizes GARY and DENISE, bringing up the rear Sarone notices as Cale lowers the gun. Sarone reaches the barge, picks up what he's been draggin and throws it onto the deck. It lands with a heavy splat. HIDEOUS, HAIRY CREATURE. ‘ SARONE Wild boar. Gores.with its tusks. Goes for the eyes. These two are lucky to be alive. (full of adrenaline) sO You should've seen it, man! What a shot! “ He just blasted it. DENISE . (still in shock) Yeah. Great. “Sarone looks at Cale, smiles strangely. A pause... - ’ 1 From now on, let's stay on the boat at night.

dialogues.text: - Am I on? DANNY . Not unless you're a big 'ol creépy lookin' wooden snake. Westridge looks towards the totem, even he is impressed. Terri's eyes are on Sarone as he surveys the river. Saron points to the right. :

dialogues.text: According to the lunar charts they would be on that side. *. Cale points to the left.

dialogues.text: This marker would indicate the Shirishama are this way. Cale locks at the totem.

dialogues.text: What makes you sure it's Shirishama?

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: The snake. The Shirishama worship giant snakes-- anacondas-- as gods, protectors. This marker shows the Queen Anaconda. The mother of all snakes. They've handed . down the legend of their ancestors making a.trek to a sacred lake, the first part of the passage is a waterfall protected by warrior snakes. If you made it past the guardians you would travel through the land of the anaconda until you came upon a wall so > high it blotted out the sun-~

dialogues.speaker: CALE
dialogues.text: --and follow the wall for five days, finally reaching the end: the head of a giant anaconda. There to guard the lake for them, to keep the innocent from its poisoned waters. en SARONE You know the ‘s:

dialogues.speaker: CALE
dialogues.text: Yes. But ‘snake myths don't tell us where the tribe is. . on

dialogues.speaker: SARONE
dialogues.text: I know where they are. I trap snakes for a living. Cale looks at Terri. CALE . And I'm sure you're very good at it. I locate Tribes for a living...and I'm very good at that. (CONTINUED)

TERRI turns to see Sarone at her side; beyond her we make ripples in the water, moving away from the boat; neither Terri nor Sarone notice the ripples. Sarone has shaved an put on a clean shirt. He leans toward her with a tangible physical charge. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: ‘SARORE I startled you. sorry.

dialogues.text: : No problem.

dialogues.text: Don't take it personally, sarone. My research is fairly extensive and I'd like to test it. : SARONE — (laughing) The jungle isn't a laboratory. This isn't college. This is a living, breathing thing...with a personality...and a voice. Pay attention and you'll hear it. Cale rolls his eyes.

dialogues.text: It seems that the twigs and flowers are collected by the young men...they signify growth, the cycle of the forest, fertility...the men weave the wreath in a special interlocking way. The two strands becoming one. Then they add the feathers to represent the feeling of their heart as it soars. Terri smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CALE
dialogues.text: And on certain nights...after the rainy season...when the moon is new...the men present the wreath to the woman they love asa kind of, well, marriage proposal. Cale looks up at the moon. Terri follows his look and, su enough, it's a new moon. Terri looks Cale directly. in th eyes. They kiss. Tenderly at first...then hungry, passion
